trial_identification.studytitle: It's Your Move! A community-based obesity prevention study in secondary school children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A 3-year study in secondary school children of a multi-strategy, community intervention promoting healthy eating and physical activity compared to no specific interventions on changes in body size and composition

interventions.interventions: Interventions are multiple strategies over 3 years within secondary schools and the community to build the community's capacity to promote healthy eating and physical activity. Examples include school food policies, improving school food service, within school and after school physical activity programs, training for coordinators and student ambassadors, curriculum on healthy eating and healthy bodies, activities around avoid ing fad diets and creating body size acceptance, social marketing, incorporating programs into local government strategic plans.
interventions.comparator: Comparison group is exposed to background activities in the region with no specific intervention strategies instituted.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline (2005) and at follow up (2008 or before as student leaves school)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Body mass index, body mass index z-score, prevalence of overweight and obesity, waist circumference, behavioural indicators of healthy eating and physical activity, quality of life, and knowledge indicators.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: All will be measured at baseline (2005) and at follow up (2008 or before as student leaves school). School audits and community capacity measured in 2005 and 2008.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Students in Years 7-11 in selected schools in intervention and comparison areas.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: School of Exercise and Nutrition Sciences, Deakin University

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of this study is to test the impact of a community-based program aimed at promoting healthy eating and physical activity on changes in weight and body fat in adolescents. The hypothesis is that a community and student-led health promotion approach will reduce the levels of overweight and obesity in this group.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Secondary schools in the Barown-SW region of Victoria. Approved by Deakin University Human Research Ethics Committee
Secondary schools in the Barown-SW region of Victoria. Approved by Catholic Education Office
Secondary schools in the Barown-SW region of Victoria. Approved by Department of Education and Training
